14 November
Dear Mr. Conroy,
This came addressed to me with a little note from Mr. Feikenia saying that he wanted us to see what he was writing you, and would we please forward it to you after we'd read it. I made a copy for a possible quote, & here's the original.
Sincerely,
Eileen Kelly

[[ANNOTATED in pencil Aaron, A.J.
Anaheim, CA]]
12/20/89
Dear Jack,
At long last, I am impelled to write. I have received a letter from Douglas Wixson asking my aid -- such as I am able to give in his effort to bring you some of the recognition denied you for so long. Believe me, I'll do my best in such a cause. Although, alas, I have only my memory to aid me.
You have met my younger brother, Chester. You undoubtedly know through him, the love, respect and admiration I have for you. That I have always had.
I am told you had your 91st birthday last Dec. 5th. On Dec. 10th I had my 82nd. As a young man to his mentor, I salute you. It is through no fault of yours that I stopped writing, and it is to your eternal

credit that you kept alive the flame of hope to those who would not - and could not stop, such, for example, as my brother Chester. Simply to know you was enough.
Best
Abe
A.J. Aaron
311 La Reina St,
Anaheim, Cal,
97801

ANNOTATION in red pencil in margin begins
head. His description of himself to me: "I am an aesthete...I don't believe the C P speaks the language of the American.worker...Boy, am I having a helluva a good time writing this story (his first novel)...Lend me Das Kapital, will you, Abe (I left it in the coffee shop for a period of two weeks. Each of us went in daily, though seldom at the same time. He never striken pickcsd read the thing)...I don't believe the American workers will ever stand for any kind of dictatorship...The Daily News advanced me ten dollars on a story...Have some coffee...Have you read the Humanists...Goddamndest crap...I'm not going to write for the newspapers; I've kept my work pure so far and I'm not going to stop now...The Daily News..."
I believe the boy is honest enough. He always impressed stricken letter me as being slightly cracked. And, though I have not read the stricken word Nation review, I believe that fundamentally he attacks you because he believes you are sectarian and regimented. I believe there is a neurosis there, his honesty, already mentioned, being that to be expected of one whom I might describe a socio-pathologic neurotic. He is a Mencken of the proletariat without Mencken's critical stricken word faculty, an embryonic fascist from the depths attempting to flower on the heights. But he does have n ear for idiom and a background which might make him a proletarian except for the fact that he is so confused philosophically that I doubt that he ever will emerge.
ANNOTATION red pencil in left margin ends
Comradily,
Abe
P.S. I'll send you the money for the book about 1/18, for the 5 magazines about two weeks later. Better send me ten of #5. My family, my friends etc. will want copies. My mother is very sick. Out of the hospital now, but too weak even to walk about the house.
Don't think I am always expecting answers to letters. I don't answer (or write at all for that matter) so often myself.
I'm going to make a stab at review of [Hicks?] last. I doubt that I shall submit for #4 of Left Front, though I may. Jordan says, "Why not?" I don't think I ought to get in my own paper in every issue with both story and review. I wish I hadn't made stricken My  my "From the Far East" so speculative in tone. Some good comments on my story have come into the office, but none of the kind of criticism like yours which gives me a guide for study and correction.
Abe

1421 E. 66th Place
Chicago, Ill.
February 23, 1934
Jack.
Will you curse me a lot when you hear I'm out of work + broke? What I owe you (75c - 5 magazines) I'll pay as soon as possible. There was a change in managership at the hotel. Ergo - 
I've been unemployed for a month. I may go home. I may stay - I want to remain in Chicago. But how I shall manage to do it I'll be damned if I know.
I haven't done any writing for over a month. I've been elected to the section committee and it's taken too much of my time. When I demured on the request of the community to accept, I was assured the work assigned me would not be excessive. Yet it has. Now, I must make my decision. Will I write or will I continue as an acted section functionary? When I told the committee how I felt, saying, was it a question of writing or of the section committee, I must choose writing, I was accused of individualistic tendencies. Hell. I tried to explain, its not a question of giving up party work but, rather, of giving up one type of party work. It didn't go over so well. Now, in a case like this, what is one to do? I wonder if Mike Goldever faced this problem
I find in the party that the J.R.C. is regarded disdainfully and with tolerant amusement by a great number of comrades. They do not regard it as important party work. Now, of course, stricken I admit I understand that trade union, basic, work is stricken at the moment of prime importance. But, also, I contend that writing is what I think I am fitted for and is what I want to do, and that the problem is to find how, as a writer, I can aid in basic work.
Isn't it hell? You see I like the section work. But I want and demand that I be allowed time to study and to write. I think I can do both, when and if the work of the section is properly allocated among the members of the committee. But how long that when and if?

Another thing. My family would like me to come home. Carfare + telephone in the city are ruining me. I've already had to borrow. It won't take long for source to dry up.

   Jack, I mean to write. But what am I going to do about the party? I want both, and I can't go back to the rank and file now, giving up my section position, without causing misunderstanding and the conclusion that I deviate from and do not understand the party line. It's a sweet problem.
   I have thought of sending the problem to Mike. His answer should be interesting. First, however, I'd like to hear what you have to say. If you want, you may send this letter to Mike; if you think he might tackle the problem I face, that is, if you think he would be interested in it?

Abe
P.S. Why the hell won't the Daily return manuscripts - even though self addressed, stamped envelopes are enclosed for the purpose by the writer? Return manuscripts? Hell, you can't get even an answer to a letter about the mss.
Abe

Dec 7, 1966
Dear Jack - 
How good to get a letter from Missouri + to find it's from you.
My book, ABOUT US, is being published April or May by McGraw-Hill. It's about a Jewish family in a Penna mining-town before + during World War II. It's only taken me 20 years to get published + you 30 to be re-published. Is there a moral here somewhere? Anyway, I have you on the list for copies. I hope you like it.

  I wish I could say I've read Any Place But Here. I haven't. I now will. The Time of the Hero scares me a bit because it's so close to what I'm beginning to work on now.
  Anyway, I thank you for your note. I will call your daughter-in-law + grandson. I return your greetings, in, you'll excuse the expression, spades.
  Incidentally, did a Constance Pearlstein get in touch with you regarding Dick Wright? She's writing a biography, with Ellen's OK.

Best Regards, always -
Chester

Sept 1, 1967
Dear Jack:
What a good review. Many, many thanks.
Your stories about editors scare me. I think I'll send my books directly to the people, without editor or publisher. No publicity, no reviews, just sales.
A guy in NY - a Mr. Becker - is interested in buying the movie option for ABOUT US. Nothing final yet. I hear a rumor that Ronald Reagan is going to resign as governor so he can play Poppa in the movie. And Shirley Temple will be Momma. Oy!
I'm sending off a chunk of the next book tomorrow. I wonder what the reactions will be. I'll let you know.
Incidentally, when was that picture in Robert Cromie's column taken? When you had your bar-mitzva?
And what do you do in Moberly? Write? Read? Spit tobacco juice across the street into Mrs. Hasenflu's window-box?
Those little inserts you always include are heart-warming. I feel much more at ease knowing that there are spirits concerned with such esoteria. God's in his heaven, all's right with the world. All's right with California, + I doubt the state will ever go left.
Jack - greetings, my love + when do you journey to God's country?
Chester

May 20, 1972
Jack:
Onward + upward.
Did you receive a copy of my just published "Better Than Laughter"? Please let me know. It's been getting very good to moderate reviews, with NY Times (a librarian reviewed it) panning it. Stupid review. Published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, which is also publishing another one in Feb, 1973. 

 How are you? Did Wallace really say "Don't y'all dare bus me to no hospital."?
 Jack: Is paperback of Disinherited available? I want to use it for my seminar on Tradition + Change next Fall. (20 copies) Yes, I'm teaching at a Catholic College. It's crazy. The "Christian Brothers" live in the 18th, not the 19th, century. Fascists, stupid + insensitive. But I love teaching. I'm working for an MA at SF State College so I can get a better job in a better college so I don't have to return to hospital work (about which I'm writing my own Disinherited so I can continue writing. Thank you for that lovely American Book Collector. You're a rare, good man. Wish we could talk. Where will you be the 3rd week of August? I'm coming East. Maybe down South?

Regards
Chester

June 18, 1972
Dear Jack:
Thanks for all your letters, enclosures, and support. You are a good man + shall end up somewhere near heaven (after all, you're neither Eastern nor Jewish.)
I feel righteous + pure, having read all of your epistles. If you persist on converting me, please convert me not into a Baptist or a Lutheran or what have you. Convert me into a cello. I'd love to be cradled between the thighs of a lovely young cellist (but what if I get picked up by Pablo Casals?)
Anyway, the sage of Moberly seems content + well. I like your reviews. Where the hell do you get the time to read them all?
Am planning to be east Aug 14-20. If the heat doesn't get me down I might very well travel to Moberly to see you.
Will certainly let you know in time.

 Am having another "young adult" book published in Spring. A good one. Better than BETTER THAN LAUGHTER. Am trying to convince Harcourt to dispense with the labels "Young Adult", "Children's Novel", "10-14", "14-up", etc.

As of June 24, for 6 weeks, I stricken can will be at: c/o Rosenberg, 2428 Dowling Place, Berkeley, Calif 94705. Then, I don't know. Will keep you posted.
Regards + Thanks -
Chester

Sept 9, 1972
Dear Jack - 
Was in NY for 1 week, hated it, couldn't wait to get back to Calif. Heat + humidity laid me flat. So, as you know by now, I never got to Moberly (nice title for a song: I never got to Moberly, I live too soberly, ya ya ya  four musical notes)
Your KC Star review was superb. I thank you much. Have ordered 20 copies Disinherited for seminar (I ordered them even before I saw your review) + may end up ordering another 20 for a 2nd seminar. Spoke to Norman Springer. He remembers you fondly. In fact it was Norman + his wife, Mary, who got me to St Marys, when I was fired from the hospital. They are true + rare friends.
Thank you for all your circulars, epistles, journals. Have subscribed to the new New New Anvil.

  Have not seen Abe for 3 years. Have talked to him. He seems bitter, even unhappy. But each man picks his wife + life + strife.
  Talking about that: Margaurite + I separated after an 18 year marriage. We might eventually get back together. In the meantime, after what was, most of the time, a good marriage, we split. We see each other, talk, + share $ 50-50. It's rough. First 4 months were real culture shock. Adjusted fairly well now.

Jack, my love, my thanks, my regards. -
Chester

pencilled note at top of page  Aaron, Chester
July 1, 1977
Dear Jack:
And Christ said: "What are you idiot disciples doing, standing there in the heat all day?" (Ultra new Testament, Kings + Queens, Ch 2, Pg[h?], line 644.)
I arrived here in The Holy Land (Holy Hell! It is hot!) June 14th, will be leaving July 14th, returning to San Francisco. I have not written to you, nor heard from you, for years, + here, in Jerusalem, I remember the many missles your letters contained + so I send you now a missle of my own.
How are you? I think of you often. My silence does not mean any loss of love or respect. It only means sloth, indolence, + the greatest of these is inactivity. I've spent every spare minute of every spare hour these past few years, sneaking off to the ranch to write. Result: in 5 years I've completed 4 novels + 5 stories. Fourth novel, also for "young adults" (about an oil spill) comes out in August. Am half way through a sequel to About US.

 The last 2 weeks I've performed the usual pilgrim's trick: The Old City (Arab) in Jerusalem, about one fiftieth of the various mosques, synagogues, tombs; as well trips to Masada, Herodion, Caesarea, Gilboa (did you know that Saul + Jonathan died here?), Hazor (seat of the Canaanite king defeated by Joshua; one of the largest archeological sites in the country; Hyksos fortress, Canaanite + Israelite altars;) etc, etc. I have spent most of my nights meeting novelists, poets, playwrites, etc - + also politicos. Of course everyone here is a politico. The sleaziest, dumbest, most cynical storekeeper is an authority. On what? On anything. You pick it.

Most disconcerting, & most impressive sight: the streets filled with soldiers carrying loaded rifles & machine guns. (Not a drunk in the streets.) Can you imagine the carnage in LA, SF, NY, if our soldiers & marines were permitted to carry loaded weapons on weekends?
I leave in less than 2 weeks. Will be living again at the ranch (PO Box 75, Bodega, California 94922.)
Jack, my friend, take care. My love to you --
Chester Aaron

Dear Jack: 
I'll be delighted to write a letter for you and hope very much that it may have some influence. In a few hours I'll be enlightening Sussex students on the election. Two months out of the States make the election seem pretty remote but I shall try to dispell some of the simplistic notions current here. Haven't seen Jim Powers yet but hope to, and when/if I get to Paris, I'll look up your friend.  I'm too rushed now to write further but will later.
good luck
Dan

letterhead
SMITH COLLEGE
NORTHHAMPTON, MASSACHUSETTS
DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH
Dear Jack: a copy of my book should have been in your hands several weeks ago, but that doesn't excuse my dilatoriness in writing to you about my progress. I've written again to Harcourt - Brace about the delay in sending your copy but I suspect the letter and the book will arrive together. I kept the magazines (which I didn't use very much given the point of view and content of the book - I mean I write of the authors rather their works) because I'm going to do an anthology of the 30's for Amber Press (I plan to include a section from The Disinherited) - but I'll send it immediately.

 About the book - I can't say. Sometimes I think it's lousy - sometimes it seems all right. I'll be eager to

get your opinion. You'll notice that I make J.T. Farrell a rotten sour apple.

  I am very probably coming to Chicago this year but I don't know when. But I'll write before I come and I hope we can have an evening together. I thank you for your help in my preface - but I do so more personally here. You were swell and I appreciate it.

Best wishes to you Jack and good luck
Dan Aaron
P.S. I told H-B. Your address was Midlothian -: book is being sent there.
pencilled note:   [1960's ?]

pencilled note     [1975]
letterhead
HARVARD UNIVERSITY
DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH AND AMERICAN LITERATURE AND LANGUAGE
WARREN HOUSE
CAMBRIDGE, MASSACHUSETTS 02138
Dear Jack:
I was glad to get your Christmas note with your backward glance at the Hooverville days. I don't know whether or not we shall merely be recessional and avoid being depressional but I don't have much confidence in the Admiral who's now trimming the sail of the Ship of State or in the recently elected Vice-Admiral.

  Pretty soon I'll be reading the examination papers of students who have read The Disinherited and getting ready for next term. It's been a rough year, what with extra teaching assignments, committees, and lots of outside tasks. 
  I hope things are going swimmingly in Moberly. Some time I'd love to visit you in your native habitat and have some long

talks, but in the meantime - my warmest greetings, Jack, and all my best wishes for the coming year.
Dan

pencilled note   Aaron, Dan
letterhead
HARVARD UNIVERSITY
DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH AND AMERICAN LITERATURE AND LANGUAGE
WARREN HOUSE
CAMBRIDGE, MASSACHUSETTS 02138
May 18, 1984
Dear Jack:
In these ghastly times when a great stink emanates from Washington and the Republic is floundering in shit creek, I'm sustained by the evidence that at least one prophet is being honored in his own community.
I wish I was there in Moberly to attend the festivities but at least I can extend warm greetings to you from still chilly Cambridge.

 This term (I'm now emeritus at Harvard) I taught in Austin, Texas

in August I'm lecturing in Japan and probably China, but I haven't given up my plan to visit you in Moberly.
All the best, Jack, and enjoy the accolades. You deserve them.
With warm affection
from your friend
Dan Aaron

yyyyyyyyyyyyy
Dear Jack:
I feel like a heel for not having written before this - (to hell with this dammed machine.  Now you must read my interestingly illegible script), and for not having returned your magazines to you.   I have them neatly stacked in  my office, from which I have never removed them, and i only need them now to check references.  The book is just about done, alltho it's turned out to be a different sort of book than I had originally intended - not in every respect but in some respects.  It is, I suppose, a chronicle of the impact of the idea of Communism {?} socialism on the { ? } writer.  Half of it deals with the period before 1929, half (or maybe a little less) after 1929. I stop in the early 40's.  Joe {Freeman} likes the  first half but has misgivings about the second part -   which seems to come down pretty much to intramural bickerings, ...series of disenchantment, ... sharpshooting, ideological careerism etc. Just to temper this {somberness}   a little, I've inserted a chapter which will {open up? }    the thirties - Part II of my book.  There is a twist to the idealism and its magnanimity of the decade and a critique against those who would dismiss the {soldiers} as {crooks} and {murderers} - as if there were no objective reasons why anyone should want to reconstruct our society or oppose Hitler.

There is not enought space, unfortunetly, to deal
with the (literature) itself in any detail since the writers,
not their works, are my chief concern here. But I
intend to follow the work up with a kind of
sequal which will interpret the (literature) of the
writers as the most () exploration into the
cranies and by-ways of American life ever undertaken.
Well - happy New Year Jack. I hope to hell
we can meet before the year is through. I intend
to make every effort I can to see you in Chicago.
I'll return you little mags safe and sound
shortly.
Best wishes as always
Dan

SMITH COLLEGE
MEMORANDUM
In re
Dear Jack - 
Just a note to thank you for the
notebook and letters. I'm trying to get ready
for my year in Poland and will probably write
my introduction for the {??} in London - in time
thor the other deadline. Don't worry about
Farrell. I'm really more interest in pulling your
mind in its proper context - and showing, many
the (map), when it might be read in American
Literture courses. I'm just re read it - an
it certianly holds up despite the allegedly
"dated" qualities. and that is more you
wrote it simply and sincerely. The so-called

"marxist" aspects are less important -; what
is important is its demonstration (art?) scenes of
men's life hither to unrelfected in American Literture
are intended with dignity. What holds up especially
in the time - neither shrill nor querelous.
I'll be keeping in touch - 
Warmest greetings
Dan

Dear Jack:
Thanks much for your letter. I'm hoping to return your
magazines (??) As late Spring or early Summer.
The book is slowly - (?) slowly - moving to a close. I 
hopt to hell that (?) & Want publish the (desesheulca)
I shall (?) them (?) season a letter as I can advocating
that they get it out in a hurry.
I think you are too modest, in retrospect, about
(Amd?). There's an aspect of the (Parttson?) Review story that
isn't so pretty. What strikes me more and more as I (?)
in the literary imbrogiey of the 30's is the careerism
that lay behind the zeal of merry (voices). This was
particulerly true, I think, of the NY City contingent
and Messers Rohw and Phillips especially.
I've been going through UF Cavlerton's papers and
have found some letters of yours. Dear Denner also
(showes) me a few you had written just after
The Disinherited. Saw Joe Freeman a few days ago.

I'll write you a proper letter pretty soon.
I'm working my tail off now and wish many
day had 48 hours. Let's hope Hall & Wang or vice
versa come through.
Enjoying "The Modern Darros" particularily.
Best wishes Jack
and good luck
Dan

SMITH COLLEGE
NORTHAMPTON, MASSACHUSETTS 01000
DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH
Dear Jack: Enclosed are clippings you sent
to me. Many thanks for it (came) to see them.
I read - and reviewed - some of the works you
did, not I () to review the Gilbert
with it PR (brunure?) I didn't like the way it
was written and am annoyed by the title - which
(bolnpies) the contents. The Wright biography contained
some interesting stuff - new to me - but I am
still a little disappointed with it.
If you get the England this year -
please let me know. My address is simply
Univeristy of Sussex, Arts Building, Falmer-
Brighton, England. I think you ought to
have a grant to organize your stuff - and I'll
put my mind to it.
Best
Dan

Oct. 2, 1970
Dear Mr. Conroy,
Enclosed you should find a copy of the newsletter you gave me as well as the write-up about you. Thank you for letting me use them.
We really enjoyed your visit. Sorry that our financial means did not allow us to make you more comfortable. I hope we can get together again soon.
I haven't had a chance to read Anyplace But Here yet I did read The Disinherited. I can't find words to describe it. It was one

-2-
of the most powerful and moving books I've ever read. People tell me that a lot of the book was in a way autobiographical. If that is true, I feel as though I know you much better. I'm very anxious to read Anyplace But Here now.
Take care of yourself & I hope we see you again soon.
Love,
Jean Aarstad

Oct. 26, 1970
Dear Jack,
It was good to hear from you today. I enjoyed the enclosed bits of wisdom you also send!! We will be sending copies of the Tack to the people you listed.
We felt bad for not being able to all come to Columbia but other plans & lack of cars caused a problem. Hope we can make it over there some time soon.
You asked about Deadwood Dick. The first performances will be Sat. Oct. 31 with a big cast party afterwards. It would really be great if you, Dear Beery & anyone else who might like to come, would be able to come over for the big night. If you're interested, maybe you can talk to Dave [?] about it. We would surely like

-2-
to have you come. It starts at 8:00 P.M. If you can't make it this week-end, it will be put on each Fri. and Sat. night for at least 4 weeks.
We have been very busy working on getting the play & building in shape as well as contacting people for a possible hootenanny schedule in the near future. This leads to very hectic days and nights.
Well, must sign off for now. Write when you have time & let us know what's going on.
Hope to see you this week-end!
Yours in the struggle,
Jean
AARSTAD
FOLKU.

August 2, 1933
To the Comrades of the Rebel Poet.
Companion Jack Conroy: some time ago
I received with great pleasure your great
review of poetry. It seems magicifient
modern, + evolutionary to me. I have
always wanted to tell you this. In
Spain and countries of language 
a similar cue is lacking. Three years
ago I shouted to make the poetry
international and revolutionary,
one poem of the classes in 
collaboration. all the poets of the
world who are interested in make and
forming the revolutionary epic
of the time. Do you believe this
could be realized: I lack disposition
to be able to be the manager of
this great enterprice. I await

your decision on this. At all events,
I think you could make a manifestation
to spread our points of view in
regard tot he great collective
poome. If you can say something
in your review about this, I 
should be very grateful to you. Then
we can be in harmony to compile
the declaration. What do you think
about it

June 16, 1974
Dear Jack
Just suppose this
person (me) were into
writing this novel to
be entitled "Caseworker."
After enduring the most
crashing changes
that probably any State's
Department of Welfar has
ever gone through that 
quickly. (Just quit the job.) Written
from a caseworker point

2)
of view + better done than
"Up The Down Staircase."
So far, I have sketched
several "novels" and
plays this spring +
written nothing but 2 or
3 poems. Also choked
out a about 3 typed
pages of a 1st champer
that should stand up.
Is there any chance I
could get paid for this
on the strength of my 
poems? Once I have

3)
actually a chapter or
2 really down, plus
outlline?
My scarrered room contains
3 reams of paper, nice old
typewriter, and many types
of notes on character, one
start of a play + another
full outline of a play.
Tonight I got bumpily
past my last sort of
jam up on the book + got
ahead of myself a little

4)
too. What would you
suggest?
Your friend,
Carol
ACKLVNP

Chicago
December 6, 1974
Dear Jack
I've had a strange, transitional fall.
Decided to go to the country all the way
and went. Spent October on my uncle's
farm near Albert Lea, Minnesota. Harvey
time for acres, horizons of rolling fields.
These mammoth combines with little cabs
way up thake care of the field corn and the
soybeams. My one uncle got 28 bushels
per acre on his soy banes comparied to
42 last year. I really love sothern
Minnesota + t was fun to be there. I
worked as a waitress in this local cafe
and felt at one with all the local
Scandinavians, if not the noisy little
Greeks who own and run the place. You
drive out under a stary country sky
at 5:30 a.m. and are really supposed to smile
a real lot at all the regulars once you
make the coffee. (Told one of the men I saw the Northern lights and he sort of leaned over the counter a little more + took a big drive of his coffee)
So I returned to Chicago + got a job in

a shelter care home for old people +
somewhat sick people - basically all
ambulatory + trained + all I'm a
social rehabilitation worker + seriously there
is some challenge there.
I'm wondering what to read. I was thinking
tonight that there is so little good prose.
Maybe it's my fault - I've taken to reading
junk in the lat few years. Novels in
Cosmopolition (1 or 2 good ones out of 15
waded through) Whats' around in the way
of novels - is it that I want old-fashioned
language? Bigger words? The books seem
so limited as to language - almost
magazine English. Or else they fool
around with it - I love Kerovac. Of 
course I must realize that I've Actually
read some best sellers - something
I gigure if I'm going to any writing, I'd

Chicago
March 1, 1975
Dear Jack
Thanks for the list! My branch library has only a few, and being a car driver now, it's more difficult to stop off in the loop. Will be doing so, tho, even if it means spending 25 ¢ for 15 minutes, limit 1/2 hour at a meter and all the brave policemen waiting to pounce.
I met Curt Johnson a couple of times. He went with my boss, John Benson, from Scott Foresman to run the then-new Britannica Press in about '62. Curt left before I came, but came back to visit and I remember seeing

December then. Liked it. We had 3 or 4 editorial directors in a couple of years. Curt went back to Scott, then free-lanced. We production assistants were selecting the books to put out for a while, as there were hardly any editors. Except me, (I didn't choose) who was working on the important Witty-Botel? Modern Math series. My boss had this list & the new little production editors chose!
I'm now in a good job for a change! Cost estimator for Consolidated Books. A good place with nice people, if somewhat helter-skelter. It's

3)
great to be back in crazy old publishing. We do super fancy, huge illustrated Bibles, dictionaries & cookbooks. 
Barbara's is as great as ever, as far as I'm concerned. It seems they have all the best books. 
We have a deal to sell New Standard, as our sales people felt we needed an encyclopedia. So we do a special binding, including a binder for the good, old quarterly. I sent in for the Foolkiller--to subscribe--& never got it. They do still publish, don't they? Have been doing some poetry & looking more critically at my stuff. Usually a part of it is OK & not the rest. It has

needed to sit & be looked at again. My sending in a whole lot of it last spring to a publisher served the function of getting out of myself. I wrote it for me & it's rough & needs to be a little different to be published. Also, I'm thinking about me as writer & getting into the discipline of sitting down and doing it and not wandering off, first for coffee, then out to a bookstore or the library & all that. I remember last spring being very sensitized & really enjoying everything.

5)
I was unhappy too--a strange time.
Our marvelous mayor has done it again, despite all upstart-independents. I'm in Singer's ward & voted for him & his protege--"Oberman for alderman." Has a nice sound. But I have some doubts--both New York & Detroit had all kinds of big, new problems after electing reform mayors. 
Spring is coming & I'm going to get my bicycle out & oil it up--may ride to work some. 
Sincerely,
Carol

Acklund, Carol
Chicago
November 3, 1975
Dear Jack
Thought you might enjoy the enclosed. It was handed to me by a blonde child under the el. Also got a couple of religious goodies, including "Hell, is it real?" handed out at 5:00 on State Street. 
Am into my writing again & am working on an article on some things I'm doing at my

2)
church. I joined this one because it is more involved with social problems than most. Then I'm going to sell it. Also, I'm going to sell cosmetics & natural soaps & vitamins (don't take iron & calcium, please, just buy it). Anyway, I'm enjoying life & my new roommate, Paula Reingold, or whatever her impossible name was.

3.
She plays the piano & paints & teaches school these days. Missed the commune a little, but it made the transition from Minnesota smooth. If I get married again, which I believe I will, it won't be right away. Have done a few more poems, but hadn't gotten around to submitting any recently. Where does Curt Johnson live now? It may be too late for December, but

4)
I don't know what suburb he's in.
I stopped by New Standard last week for the first time in yers. Bob Halasy has the quarterly & the art department gets the old axe in December. It was fun to talk with him--he has some land in Wisconsin. Yvonne is going too. Terry Tumlin has a couple of kids & has moved with her

5)
family to Atlanta. 
Am enjoying my new camera (not Brownie--instamatic) and bought a book on it because they don't come out! My old one which I lost, had a single light adjustment and one distance thing. The truck number is a dragon--they lay asphalt. The gas jets on the back part are something else. I was doing an article on it which I may sell to

6)
United Parcel Services' house organ, which I like. The old man who edits it liked the idea, but I need to check out some facts. 
I also plan to freelance a few menus, since I'm so hip to printing & all from Britannica. 
Happy New Year!
-Carol

Dear Jack
Now that I'm vacating my ground floor mod-carpeted, furnished Buffet (studio) apartment, I've gotten into a kindlier, gentler (knock-on-wood) shrink place to dry out. My possessions were starting to get greasy with a heavy odour and I had the distinct feeling of being i the way of any number of God's creatures, heretofore undreamed of by me. I'm guessing I'll be out in a week or so, though, and have gotten a few new ideas--rent furniture from a storage place.

August 11, 1980
Dear Jack
How's life in Moberly? I'm self retiring too. Have good unemployment now from operating a CRTV (cathode ray tube) computer input. The boss was young--30ish and brilliant and the whole thing is systematized. But what a time getting computerized. Then we had two great morale, dinner & drinking  parties, one right after inventory. We all did overtime for inventory, boring though its was. 
Iowa is not a flat state with nothing but low roads & high, hot corn. It is rich with birds, trees & flowers. And route 64 from Illinois to Mennesota is the prettiest. That's

where I left Chicago for the country and my country people.
I was back there in the summer of '78, all I could afford was Rogers Park, then Wilson Avenue--unsafe, but I did like it. Blew a whole team of "Managers"--apartment building in the Park. Also needed '79 with my parents & good old Minneapolis. My sisters aren't the greatest, tho my brother is. 
Enclosed one of my  more recent efforts at poetry. Improved taking a course at the Loft (Chicago & Lake) in Minneapolis. Really wonderful to poetize with a small group (about 8). 
Election time is coming up. Atlantic, (6,500 people), with its summer primary really had a hood running for County Sheriff. It was a 4-way nick-and-neck

3
with the real sheriff sinning by a good margin. Also we're going to have to poll watch & not the summer residents who like us whoring and all. Sometimes it seems that there's 10 rackets on me in 5 days.? Living yet anyway! We Norwegians always come back. Mostly alive, although I suffered a foot sprain in Denver.
Going to write sociology. One book, since a professor once challenged me, will be Chicago in the '60s and '70s. Maybe I'll do, later, a tale of 3 cities, Mpls. Denver, and, also in sociology. My fiction comes out dumb and stupid. I like regional accents & music, but I don't know if I'll ever do fiction. Happy September!
-Carol

                                                             Sep. 29, 1944

Dear Jack,

    Was disappointed, recently, when my outfit pulled out and I was transferred. New address is the 125th Evacuation Hosp. Camp Maxey. A field hospital. If you got an A.P.O address from me, just disregard it. Meanwhile, I’d like to get in touch with Ben Appel, if you have his address. 
    Bud wrote that he’d be leaning over loop bars between now and October 25 - hope I get another furlough while he’s still in town, but have my doubts. I lost a good outfit and found a miserable

one. No telling when I’ll get out of this camp now. I was on my way to the train when the transfer was effected. 

    Appel wrote me something about getting transferred to something in Washington called OSS — but I’ve lost his address. I notice that Saul Levitt is now a correspondent for YANK. That’s sure work. 
    Nothing else new. Give my best to all, and let me know what the score is. 
                           Luck,
                              Nelson

Oh Nelson, Nelson-

  I do believe things are beginning to focus. Tonight the world seems more endurable & I have a sense of direction (East!) There's no especial reason for I awoke this A.M. in the howling wilderness after dreaming that Aunt Laura was dying & winged insects were coming out of her neck. (What would a psychiatrist make of that!) But things seem possible tonight. (I had a tantalizing dream of you once that a psych. would make much of.)
  Mrs. Huff Agency phoned today & said the Calif. job was filled but that the supt. was keeping my papers because he was interested and might have another 5th grade opening in Dec. for me. I feel that I'll have a job in either Calif. or N.Y. state in a month or two -  surely by the new term in Feb. I only hope New York comes up first.

Doug found an advertisement for a correspondence course in Speedwriting in his Pop. Mech. Mag. which I intend to investigate. If I move from Missoula, it would suit my purposes more than a tutor in Gregg. 
Today I finally received my summer grades. Both Feidler & Algren gave me A's. I was sure they had something in common.

left margin   I've written to 11 NY agencies and shall register with the first 2 or 3 that send me papers promptly. The agency I had seen said they could guarantee me a job by Feb. mid-term.
right margin   Mrs. Huff Agency covers western states, but I'd only consider Calif. because of the pay.

In fact I got straight A's. in all the 14 ½ credits - even Wren's Far East, so there weren't many history MA's in that class. 

  I can't understand why I never heard from Stone. I wrote a short letter, requesting the use of his name as reference & asking about schools & living conditions in N.Y.  He offered to recommend me for an assistantship at the U. of Michigan so surely it can't be that he was insincere to that extent in his compliments of my work. Either he's as unreal as Fiedler or else something unusual has happened - illness or something. I wish I knew what the score was. What do you think?  right margin   Was everything he said a well-intentioned lie?
  I saw the write-up of "Cherry Orchard in the Times & wondered if you had seen it. Was it as "refreshingly free of traditional encumbrances" as they said?
  Did you meet Shelley Winters?  How does she compare with Monroe?
 I've been looking for classified adv's in the Times here & it finally dawned on me that that section is not mailed to Montana. How provincial can we get here!

[[[left margin]]    Aunt Laura invited Doug & me, there arrow- Lodi, Calif. for a few months' rest but I won't need to go, I'm sure. It's nice to know I could, though. Makes me think of Frost's "Death of the Hired Man"- "Home is the place where, when you have to go there, they have to take you in."

-2-

   I would like to know how the play project is developing & hope that your literary problems are more than solved - solved to your satisfaction if not delight.  Are things brighter for you now?  And when you had your interviews did you oppose Dr. Fiedler's opinion of Montana faces?  I hope you saw where duty called in that respect.
   I do hope your blessed single estate can soon be achieved without loss of your Gary roots and without a permanent financial responsibility.  I can't see how a court could expect you to support an ex-wife when there are no children to consider.   In most cases where alimony is granted for children, a wife often has trouble collecting.  I've known of many such cases.  I'm glad there was nothing like that between Norman & me.  It could be quite messy.
   Weather bright & blue there; rainy & cloudy here!   It follows me, I'll swear.
   The second studio I investigated had a photographer with more sense and less mouth.   The proofs are actually useable.  Maybe I will get a job in New York State!  Then this summer I'll try an assault on the City proper.

written in left margin   Doug carved his jack-o-lantern the other night.   Holidays do bring back memories.  Dec. is extra rough because of Christmas, Doug's birthday (10th) L's birthday 30th)  Dad's (6th) and memories of my divorce (Dec 24, 1945) and my moving from L's (Dec. 16, 1953).   Is it a hard month for you?  I'll feel relieved when it's over.

Initial attack repulsed - base camp established -  second assault planned and attempted.  Next fall could be either retreat to the Missoula job or my flag on the summit of the Empire State Bldg.  We'll see!  Anyhow - Doug & I are going to have a summer - this summer - in New York if it's humanly possible.  You don't believe it?  I'll bet you a boat trip around the island.  If we do - you take us.  If we don't we'll take you!
   In defiance of your head shaking & without respect for your experienced judgement of human fallacy

Carol
sketch of figure seated on top of Empire State Building waving flag marked C.H.
left margin
It's odd how writing to you helps.  If I'd mailed all the letters I've written, you'd have to enlarge your mailbox.  I don't want to talk to Laina & your mailbox provides an innocuous outlet.  Don't flatter yourself that it's an Emminent Author I'm writing to.  It's your mailbox.   (I never could quite digest the fact that you're a  U.S.P.  You're too real & not at all Fiedlerish.)  If you were a deaf & blind centipede with a mailbox, I'd still write.
right margin
Priscilla once said last spring she thought I had the greatest capacity for happiness of any one she had ever known.  Somehow tonight I have hope of recovering it and my sense of humor.  You met me two months too late.
[[bottom margin written sideways and upside down
I do hope you're feeling happier & freer.  When will legal proceedings start grinding?
My last letter just came back. - Just as well.  Only news - I'm not going to a psych.  I got some stuff from a Dr. but am not using it much.  Please send me your address.

Oct 11, 1967.
Dear Mr. Conroy:
My sister Hazel ?(Leabeau? suffered a cerebral hemorrhage on June 3, 1964 and was hospitalized here in a local hospital until we removed her to Chi. where I live. She is confined to a Nursing Home where she is receiving physical and speech theraphy - as I am told any degree of improvement is slow. 

 Thru out many years she has spoken of you - so much so that, I have always felt a personal interest in your book reviews in The Sun Times. I had also read, with much interest of your collaborations with Arna Bontemps

Many times when she visited me in Chicago she spoke of her desire to revise and shorten her dissertation: "Wilberforce's Speeches on The Abolition of The Slave Trade". As you may know she received her Ph.D in speech in 1959 (Ironic, indeed, that she has lost hers). The Dean had urged her to revise it for publishing as it was a timely subject because The Civil Rights Movement. Not necessarily for popular interest but as a part of history.

  After a painful and disappointing four years at a scribbled out Nq Negro Uni in Ohio - she returned here and had planned to write and do speech theraphy - sic
 Can you advise if there are Writers who might revise this material? A publisher who might see

some sale demand?
Basically, how can I find out - just in case I might be passing up something that be done in her behalf. 

Im here packing her things - books and treasures of a life time. I shall be here another ten days - after that my address is 9433 Forest Wa 8-5979 (Chi, Ill.)- Telephone here is 636-7760.

There is a copy of the dissertation here. 
If you have questions, or if you prefer to answer by telephone, please call me
Sorry I had to make this so long.
Sincerely
(Mrs) Blanche Alphran.

Mr. Jack Conroy

Dear Mr. Conroy, 
This letter is a follow-up on a telephone call you and Louis Landa had just about one month ago in regard to appearing in Joliet for The American Assoc. of University Women. The delay was unavoidable

inasmuch as our board meeting was not held until the past week. 

  At that time the board members decided - most enthusiasticly sic - that they would like to have you present a talk on your "specialty"- American literature and Social problems.
 Could you appear for our program at 8 p.m. on Tuesday evening April 22, 1947? (4th Tues. of month)  We can arrange at a later time to meet you and take you from depot to the meeting place, etc. 
 What would be your fee for such an appearance? We can afford a small stipend and traveling expenses. 
 We would appreciate being able to complete these arrangements before our yearbook goes to press the first of October.
 Many of our member are active "creative writers" and several have heard you speak, you might like to know. However, this lecture of yours' would not be from their technical

viewpoint but of a more general appeal I should imagine. 

  I do hope you can arrange to appear before our group in Joliet. 

Sincerely yours,
Helen Harshbarger
President 
Joliet Branch
Am. Assoc. of University Women

[header- Mrs. Howard F. Harshbarger - Plainfield - Illinois]
September 30 1946
Dear Mr. Conroy,
The Board of Joliet AAUW is delighted to know that you will come Joliet for our April meeting. We think that your topic as you phrase it promises to be most illuminating. Within the framework you have suggested please feel free handle the material as you wish.

 Our group has a total membership of about 75 as a rule. The figure for this

year has not yet been determined. Our budget does not permit payment of large sums for programs and $25.00 would be a great deal for us to manage. Could you see fit to talk to us for $15.00 plus the round trip railroad fare? We are eager to hear you and hope that you can come to us for this fee. If our organization "raised money" for its programs this would be no problem, but we merely have annual dues which must be stretched to cover our many activities. For what it may mean to you - I can assure you of an eager, intelligent and seriously interested audience. 

  May I hear favorably from you on this?
  Early in April I shall again communicate with you to arrange for meeting you on that evening.

Most sincerely
Helen Harshbarger

Dear Jack -

    Just a couple of items for The Conroy Archive of U.S. Culture.
    How about a literary Renaissance? I’ve finished my satirical fantasy but I wonder about publication. I’m pleased to see that Algren’s book is getting a big play but haven’t read it or any other current fiction for some time.

Think I'll start with Simone de Beauvoir's latest.

   The folksong book has been well spoken of widely but little reviewed. Sales are low, I think, for this series - I guess about 5000 so far. 
  All my two children and wife away now and for weeks to come. Please drop in - any time.

16 Nov 58
Dear Jack-
I'm sorry to hear about all your troubles with the death of your son-in-law. And I can see that how less than ever will you have energy for the memoirs I suggest. Just the same, I still urge you to think of doing something on it. Isn't there a Maecenas or a Foundation that would at least supply you with tape and recorder? You could then freely associate in very odd and rare moments with a minimum of effort.

   If you can find any urban material for me in your files, I'll be

-2-
pleased. It's a shame that so much has been lost since The Golden Thirties.

  I must confess that this year, for the first time, I altogether forgot about International Cat Week, and I thank you for reminding me. I've tried to do my part by applauding when an elderly gentleman across the street put out a saucer of milk for stray cats. In general, I don't fight the good fight the way I used to but stand always ready to cheer on those who do. As for the explanation about corn and babies, that was a revelation! I had thought that people did it just for fun and with no other purpose. 
  The course has had a small registration and attendance. However it's good for me to keep on doing a little teaching now and

-3-
letterhead  15 Charlton Street    New York 14, N.Y.
then- even with New School types who are pleasant, intelligent, but rather allergic to any form of serious effort.

  No, I didn't know that Hexter had gone to St. Louis - not a bad place, I gather. I'm still mad at him for doing an inacurate, misleading (even if maybe not dishonest and malicious) job of Marxist-baiting on me in his little book on More's Utopia. No doubt he has many virtues but I believe he brings more confusion scribbled out- that than order into historiography. Well, I comfort myself with the thought that there has hardly

-4-
ever been a better time for congratulating one's self on one's failures. The next one I'm planning is a picaresque novel, probably about a seaman. My brother is being "let go" from The Anthropology Dept. at The Univ. of Wis. after a good many years, and so I have hopes for him.

  As for The literary Thirties, maybe I should try an exploratory article or two one of these days instead of aiming too far off at a book. One of my biggest problems is too damn many projects - enough for three or nine lives. I'll write you for help whenever I get going on some aspect of The Thirties.

Yours, as ever,
Russ

Dear Jack-
This is mostly to warn you briefly that I'll probably try to get in touch with you sometime Saturday to Monday. Though I realize that a Labor Day Weekend is a hell of a time to try to see anyone or even to be alive.

   We are all four (G. bless us every one) visiting Brother David (another four) in a jolly little beach house for a few days. Then will be with my Mom (He may bless her too) on Saturday the 30th then in Chgo Sunday & Monday. Fly to Newark Tuesday noon, the 2d of Sept. 
  I'm not counting on being able to see anyone. The kids will probably gawk through two or three museums. Possibly my Sis will be back from California.
  Did I write (I think I did) that I'll offer a course called "Folk Arts of The City" at The New School? A sort of crazy thing - about

-2

all sorts of amateur arts and semi-arts that aren't usually considered in the field, like cooking & home decoration and writings on walls (of subways, latrines, etc.).

  Anyway, I've seen Ben Botkin a couple of times & like him a lot & he sends you greetings (special) if I see you. 

Yours, 
Russell
(AMES)

written in pencil
16 Dec 58
Dear Jack & Gladys -

  No Xmas cards (or pens) here, but thanks for yours, & Jack's note.
  I have more advice, or questions.   Jack, why don't you do an article for American Heritage o(or other) before finishing The Rosewood Casket?  This occurs to me because I'm thinking a piece on teenage folklore (autograph albums, camp songs, gags & jokes), wholesome & non-Freudian for this publication.  Or even Reader's Indigestion.

written in ink
20 Dec.
Also my old roomie at old Harvard, Duncan B. M. Emrich, while chief of folk at The Library of Congress, had a piece once (I've learned recently)

-2-
on tongue-twisters in American Heritage.  So it would seem a fairly good bet for you.   But shucks, you know ten times as much about publishing as I do.

  My course at the School had small registration - 4 I believe - and these I managed to drive away.   Then another 4 registered & I've had individual attendees for separate sessions to a few faithful ones who like my stuff very much.   All in all it's been rather discouraging but basically, I suppose, it means only that The New School & I were not made for each other.  Most of the "students" aren't.  They're agreeable, intelligent but have no real interest  in ideas or information that they don't possess already.  And of course my approach has been too militantly democratic, anti-Freudian, etc. etc.

-3-
letterhead  15 CHARLTON STREET  NEW YORK  14 N.Y.


  We're going out to our great estates today but will be coming in for various things during the holy days.  I plan to attend some Folklore Society Sessions & see a couple ancient chums here for the Mod. Lng. Assoc. meeting - one seeking a job, the other hiring (that's life.)
   Sure, I'd have flown out to hear Win:  I had plenty of time but not money.  (Urban folklore note:  sign in store window:  "Help make 14th Street green - Bring Money")
   I'll look for the new Saxton novel - like the earlier ones very much.

At the moment I'm slowly advancing on three unpaid pieces of writing - a review of Hughes' & your old collaborator Bontemps' The Book of Negro Folklore for Mainstream, a review on my pal St. Thomas More for Science & Society, a rebuttal to an article in the New York F L Quarterly which says there is no folk song of protest.
   After that I hope to start a novel (partly based on me and an older brother) while revising old MS in some kind of people's folk history of the U.S.
   Wishing you both all good,

Russ

Dear Jack,

  It was good to get your good luck note.   We continue to survive in spite of economics and institutions.
  From now on, Jack, no more dues from you.  You're officially a "member emeritus" - with all rights and privileges, whatever they are.
  I had hoped to see  you in Chicago last month.  It was a good conference, with a full program.  Young writers seem to feel sorrier for themselves than they ?need - used?    to, though.
   I talked to Doug in Minneapolis, and he caught me up on the news.  I was very sorry to hear about Gladys.  You must miss her terribly.
   My Michigan anthology with

the piece from The Disinherited came out yesterday.  I hope you held Gayle Research  up for a good fee.

  I used the Disinherited in class - 90 students - Spring term, and the kids liked it.   Did any of them write you?  I plan to use it again next term, and I will as long as it's in print, so tell H  & W that we need it.
  Doug promises to send me some more essays on you and your times & friends for MidAmerica.  I think he's going to have a fine book when it comes out.
  If all goes well, I h ope to get out to the Athens of the West next summer.  Let us know what and how you're doing.

Best, Dave

Oct 2, 1964
Dear Jumping Jack,

   You get around!  I always say it is good to do that (as long as it doesn't spread disease).  Broadens the horizons & ennobles the spirit, etc., provided you keep your Christian principles.  You did indeed send me a card from London, the which I would have answered except I didn't know where.  I hope you made it through London with your virtue unscathed.  I have heard that that is the most sinful city in the world & have often aspired to go there myself as a test of the strength of my own purity.
   Dangerous Dick was ill for awhile, but is unleashed on the world again in his full glory.   I understand he did go forth to Yaddo, though I haven't heard irrefutable proof of it.  Did he stop & see you?
   It was good to see all those fine reviews of The Disinherited.  I have been recommending it to our revolutionary student body It's in our library - at least, I ordered it.  I expect it will get more & more  adoptions as time goes on.
   Your plans for They Seek a City are great.  That should catch the great tide now surging - - only, whatta job to update it!  Wow!

My own work plows along.  I'm expecting to finish my long-suffering novel - Letters from a Madman, late this fall.   At the same time, I keep a poem going now & then.  But I do feel strangely out of it, off here in the Berkeley hills.   Where are the literary snows of yesteryear?
   That was a most honorable mention you gave me in World Progress, with even a picture of the book.  (Far better than Little, Brown has done - - I haven't seen one ad for the book as yet, & you can't get it at any of the bookstores here.)  I greatly  appreciate it!
  There have been good reviews in The Times, Monitor, Boston Globe, & a few other papers.  But that's all so far.
   I cast my pebble in the pond, by God, but nothing's rocking.
  Ah, well, let us continue to fight the good fight.  As it ?ever??.

Thine, Mad Anthony
P.S.  I may be making a tour easterly in early Dec. or Jan., giving lectures on the symposium book, & maybe readings of my own poems, or a lecture with readings, on EE Cummings.  So you know any paying groups or institutions in Chicago who might clamor for me if they knew they could get me cheap?

Dear Jack - Before I get on my own merry-go-round - here's a card anyway.  Thanks for the clipping.  I'm glad you liked the novel; I'd intended to write Nelson, too, when I saw his review.  What's his address in New Orleans?  Oh, that Merry-Go-Round of a life!!

  My merry-go-round is my long novel in the Philippines occupation.  In 3 or 4 weeks I'll be through with it - and then I'll look for a publisher.  ?Wyn? has released me.  About 2 months ago they saw the first 140 pages and were enthusiastic.  Perry wrote me with a pen dipped in bright ink.  Then, a month ago I sent them the next section, another 280 p. (this one is a whopper - some 600 pages in mss.)  and I heard about a week ago.  It was liked "Tremendously" but Perry said they felt public would not be interested in novel about "the occupation in P.I."  So, sir, I am free.
   I had enuf dough left to finance me in the writing of this novel.  "B.N. Y.S." (lousy title that the publisher picked)  did not sell a damn.  I moved from Alexandria and Government last October, bought a place in a town of 800 population, some 55 miles from NYC.  I could've gotten another Gov. job, but was fed up.  I lost my own job when my agency was wound up - and thought well that was as good a time as any to check out!  Best to you  ?Ben?

Dear Jack,

  Thursday evening didn't end for us where we left you - not even when David finally got me on the train, hiding behind my sun-glasses.  Numb for a little over an hour - then hungry, so to the dining car.  And what in the kitchen but an Indian!  Too, what was sitting across from me but a Catholic sister - went to bed immediately upon arrival in Hartford City.
  Don't need to say that the near Northside was quite an experience for me - have tried to tell David all I was thinking and feeling, but am too close to it in time still to say anything very intelligent - nearest is a strange combination of pity and fear and repulsion. Am thankful David is David and Jack is Jack - that I was with the two of you.  already, too, am looking forward to and hoping for the next time the three of us are together again - three beautiful people.
  Wonderful situation - and faces - in "Tight little Island An excellent film in spots - thank heaven it came from England rather than Hollywood - suggest a quick scotch and soda and  Villa ?Yabbos? immediately after.
  Help me keep close to David when you two are together.  Jack - speak to him of our evening together, and smile about it - then plan on another one. --

My love - Betts Arensman
